title: How Global Corporations turn Plastic into Fuel and Why Big Industry is Buying
description:
Fast-conversion case studies show plastic waste turned into jet fuel in under an hour, scalable routes for plastic waste turned into hydrogen, and a bench-scale plastic waste fuel reactor that liquefies mixed streams into usable fractions.
Small-scale energy use is already practical, with melting plastic waste into fuel to heat homes complementing a modular plastic waste fuel reactor that upgrades packaging into liquid fuel cuts.
Where it Fits Hydrogen routes can be attractive near heavy transport corridors or industrial clusters that already consume hydrogen.
Hydrogen pathways are maturing, with plastic waste into hydrogen detailing catalytic routes, and the world’s first waste plastic hydrogen plant illustrating how contaminated streams become clean H₂.
Jet-range molecules are achievable quickly, as plastic waste into jet fuel methods demonstrate rapid deconstruction kinetics and plastic waste fuel reactors document controllable distillation curves for circular polymer or fuel applications.
text:
If you have ever watched a viral clip of someone turning old packaging into liquid fuel with a microwave-style rig, you already know the hook. That do-it-yourself energy moment is real enough to spark curiosity. The bigger story, though, lives in commercial plants, refinery-ready feedstocks, and airline and shipping buyers that are already purchasing fuels made from waste carbon.

The result is a practical pathway from post-consumer plastics and even captured CO₂ to usable fuels and petrochemical feedstocks that meet industry specifications. The science behind sunlight-driven microwave-assisted pyrolysis is well documented, and it provides a friendly on-ramp to explain the mature routes the industry is scaling today.

Before we dive into the four routes that already work, you will see two patterns. First, large buyers care about specifications and reliability. Second, policy definitions decide who can claim recycling content and who earns fuel credits. Together, those two forces explain why some projects scale quickly while others stay in the lab.

Seven Fast Facts Proving Plastic-to-Fuel is Already Real

Hydrothermal plants are scaling now: Mura Technology announced a 50,000-ton-per-year Hydro-PRT® facility on Jurong Island, Singapore, positioned to process more than 60,000 tonnes of plastic waste annually as it expands.

Electrified cracking just hit a milestone: Coolbrook cracked 100 percent plastic-waste pyrolysis oil directly to ethylene and propylene at a pilot scale, while maintaining stable operation.

Conditioning trains make waste oils “cracker-ready”: Technip Energies commercialized Pure.rOil purification to remove contaminants and align boiling ranges for steam crackers.

CO₂-to-fuel is already commercial: The Kassø e-methanol plant in Denmark was inaugurated May 13, 2025, at 42,000 tonnes per year, with offtake tied to deep-sea shipping.

Aviation buyers are investing: United Airlines invested in Twelve, which produces power-to-liquid E-Jet fuel from CO₂ and water using renewable electricity.

CO₂-to-methanol deployments span multiple sites: Carbon Recycling International lists commercial and licensed projects that convert CO₂ into methanol at an industrial scale.

Frontier research is moving quickly: Recent reviews outline microwave-assisted pyrolysis fundamentals and photoreforming routes that turn plastics into hydrogen and valuable chemicals using sunlight.

Fast-conversion case studies show plastic waste turned into jet fuel in under an hour, scalable routes for plastic waste turned into hydrogen, and a bench-scale plastic waste fuel reactor that liquefies mixed streams into usable fractions.

Four Real Pathways that Already Work

Hydrothermal Conversion to Drop-In Hydrocarbons

How it Works

Hydrothermal processes expose plastics to high-temperature, high-pressure water. The supercritical water breaks long polymer chains into shorter hydrocarbons that can be refined into petrochemical feedstocks or fuel cuts. This approach tolerates mixed streams better than many catalytic routes and produces liquids that integrate into existing infrastructure.

Where it is Scaling

Mura’s Hydro-PRT plants showcase the model: site near industrial hubs, convert hard-to-recycle streams, and output stabilized liquids for downstream units. The Jurong Island project in Singapore is the latest expansion, sized at 50,000 tonnes per year with growth plans beyond 60,000 tonnes.

What Buyers Want

Refiners and petrochemical players want stable composition, tight impurity control, and predictable boiling ranges. Hydrothermal liquids can be conditioned to meet those needs, which is why you see projects co-located with crackers and refineries. For background on policy definitions that affect marketing claims, see our explainer on mass-balance rules in the European Union and the evolving U.S. regulatory posture on waste units.

Systems thinking spans industrial capacity and cleanup, from the UK’s biggest recycling plant processing hard-to-sort feedstocks to the Manta Ocean-Cleaning Yacht generating onboard energy from recovered debris.

Pyrolysis Oil to Steam Crackers with Electrified Cracking

How it Works

Thermal pyrolysis converts mixed plastics into a liquid commonly called pyrolysis oil. To feed that oil to a steam cracker that makes ethylene and propylene, operators must remove chlorine, oxygenates, metals, and fine solids, and in some cases trim the boiling range. Commercial purification trains now exist to perform that conditioning step.

Industrial Proof

Conditioning Is Productized: Technip Energies markets Pure.rOil, a purification platform that treats a wide range of pyrolysis oils so they can run in liquid-feed steam crackers.

Electrified Cracking Removes the Dilution Crutch: Coolbrook demonstrated cracking 100 percent plastic-waste pyrolysis oil in its RotoDynamic Reactor, delivering ethylene and propylene with stable coking behavior. That simplifies traceability and makes circular content easier to track.

Why it Matters

When cracker-grade specifications are met, pyrolysis oil can become a circular feedstock for new plastics, not just a combustion fuel. Small-scale energy use is already practical, with melting plastic waste into fuel to heat homes complementing a modular plastic waste fuel reactor that upgrades packaging into liquid fuel cuts.

Plastic-to-Hydrogen when Gas Beats Liquids

How it Works

There are multiple routes to hydrogen from plastics, including gasification with steam reforming, catalytic pyrolysis with in-situ reforming, and advanced processes that co-reform plastic-derived gases. These systems are useful when feedstocks are highly contaminated, when siting favors distributed units, or when hydrogen credits and local demand improve project economics.

Recent Signals

A growing body of 2025 literature consolidates catalysts, yields, and integration options for plastic-to-hydrogen, and field trials continue to refine performance on mixed streams. Those reviews provide mechanism diagrams and techno-economic guardrails you can cite in procurement and policy conversations.

Where it Fits

Hydrogen routes can be attractive near heavy transport corridors or industrial clusters that already consume hydrogen. Hydrogen pathways are maturing, with plastic waste into hydrogen detailing catalytic routes, and the world’s first waste plastic hydrogen plant illustrating how contaminated streams become clean H₂.

Sunlight and Electrons: The Frontier Moving from Lab to Pilot

Photoreforming With Sunlight

Researchers are rapidly improving catalysts that use sunlight and water to convert plastics into hydrogen and platform chemicals like formate and acetate in a process more commonly known as sunlight-driven microwave pyrolysis. These systems operate at low temperatures and pair naturally with renewable power. Recent reviews summarize pretreatment steps, reaction mechanisms, and stability challenges.

Electro-Routes You Should Watch

Electrified approaches, including joule-heated or plasma-assisted reforming, are being explored to co-convert plastics and CO₂ into syngas precursors for fuels. While these methods remain pre-commercial, they provide an important bridge between low-value waste streams and high-value molecules that heavy industry can use.

Who Buys, Why the Market is Growing, and What Decides the Winning Route

Selecting the right plastic-to-fuel pathway starts with knowing who will buy the output of the green e-fuels revolution and why. Marine carriers seek e-methanol that slots into port logistics, airlines fund power-to-liquid SAF to meet blend and safety rules, and petrochemicals demand cracker-grade liquids for circular polymers. With buyers defined, feedstock quality, energy prices, and policy incentives determine which technology wins in a given region, from plastic-to-hydrogen near industrial hubs to pyrolysis-to-cracker routes inside petrochemical clusters.

Shipping’s E-Methanol Momentum

Deep-sea shipping needs dense liquid fuels that move through existing logistics while meeting tougher emissions targets, which is why e-methanol is gaining traction. Denmark’s Kassø facility began commercial operations on May 13, 2025, supplying certified e-methanol produced from renewable power and captured CO₂. Early bunkering for vessels such as Laura Maersk signals real demand rather than pilot-only activity, and port infrastructure is scaling to handle methanol alongside conventional marine fuels.

What Bunkering Looks Like in Practice

At Kassø, solar-powered electrolysis pairs with biogenic CO₂ capture to synthesize methanol that is stored on site and transferred via standard bunkering hoses to container ships. Transparency on inputs and certification enables shipowners to count emissions reductions toward fleet targets, turning e-methanol into a practical decarbonization lever for ocean freight.

Aviation’s Power-to-Liquid Moves

Airlines operate under strict safety and energy-density constraints, so they are investing in power-to-liquid suppliers that make sustainable aviation fuel from CO₂ and water using renewable electricity. Investments like United Airlines backing Twelve demonstrate how carriers secure future supply, diversify beyond bio-based SAF, and push producers toward fuel specs that fit existing engines and airport fueling systems.

Jet-range molecules are achievable quickly, as plastic waste into jet fuel methods demonstrate rapid deconstruction kinetics and plastic waste fuel reactors document controllable distillation curves for circular polymer or fuel applications.

Petrochemicals Seek Circular Feed

When the objective is to make new plastics instead of combusting fuels, petrochemical buyers require cracker-grade liquids derived from waste plastics. This depends on two industrial capabilities. First, commercial oil-conditioning trains remove chlorine, oxygenates, metals, and heavy tails so the liquid meets steam-cracker requirements. Second, electrified steam-cracking pilots have shown that waste-plastic pyrolysis oil can be processed without relying on fossil diluents, which improves traceability for circular content and simplifies accounting for recycled material.

Carbon-To-Chemicals is Now a Market

Beyond fuels, carbon utilization is producing commodity chemicals. Commercial and licensed CO₂-to-methanol projects already convert point-source CO₂ into a platform molecule used in fuels and chemical manufacturing. Parallel progress in polymers shows how carbon captured from industry can reappear as polypropylene-grade outputs, tightening the loop between emissions and everyday materials.

Why Household and Enterprise Solutions Align

Decentralized systems like biodigesters cut methane at the home or community level, while energy-efficient aviation facilities reduce operational footprints across complex logistics. Both ends of the spectrum point to the same conclusion. Waste carbon becomes valuable when the conversion route fits local feedstocks, the offtake is real, and the policy framework rewards the environmental attributes that markets are willing to buy.

Regulatory Reality Check: The Rules that Pick Winners

Europe’s Mass-Balance Accounting Shapes What Counts

The European Commission launched a 2025 consultation to define how chemically recycled content in single-use plastic beverage bottles should be calculated through mass balance. This is a pivotal definition. If fuel use is excluded from recycled-content claims for bottles, projects will often favor routes that produce cracker-grade liquids for polymer loops rather than fuels. The Commission’s summary explains the accounting intent and the push for a level playing field across technologies. Review the official notice and industry briefs for the current wording and timing.

What that Means for Investors

If your revenue model depends on “recycled content” claims, mass-balance rules determine whether a given output stream qualifies. That is why companies pursuing pyrolysis-to-cracker and hydrothermal liquids often colocate with existing petrochemical assets in Europe. A conservative reading of the Commission’s consultation suggests polymer-loop outputs can be easier to credit than combusted fuels for bottle content targets. Cross-check the language before locking your product slate.

U.S. Compliance Context for Waste-to-Fuel Projects

The EPA finalized an Other Solid Waste Incineration (OSWI) rule in June 2025, effective August 29, 2025. While the rule targets incineration units, it influences how developers classify and permit certain waste-processing configurations. Developers should review the Federal Register text and EPA backgrounders to understand monitoring, emissions control, and siting implications for their specific technology stack. Start with the Federal Register entry and EPA OSWI pages for authoritative details.

Practical Takeaway on U.S. Siting

Compliance categories can shift a project’s cost structure and timeline. Teams should plan early for emissions testing, recordkeeping, and local permitting dialogues, especially when the configuration integrates thermal steps that regulators may scrutinize. Keep language precise in public communications to avoid conflating chemical recycling with incineration.

Route Selector: How To Choose the Right Sustainable Fuel Conversion Path

One rule governs everything: context decides the winner. The optimal route depends on four variables that interact locally: feedstock quality, energy price, nearby buyers, and policy definitions. When those are mapped correctly, the most efficient and sustainable pathway usually becomes obvious.

What Determines The Best Route

Feedstock: purity, polymer mix, contamination, moisture, and volume stability

Energy & Utilities: electricity price and carbon intensity, available steam, water, and heat

Offtake & Logistics: proximity to hydrogen users, steam crackers, ports, or airports

Policy & Credits: recycled-content accounting, fuel carbon intensity standards, hydrogen incentives

Start With Feedstock And End Use

Mixed, Dirty, Or Variable Streams with Local Hydrogen Demand

Choose: Plastic-to-hydrogen routes.

Why it fits: These systems tolerate contamination, can be distributed near end users, and can stack clean-hydrogen credits where they exist.

Best locations: Industrial hubs and heavy-transport corridors that already consume hydrogen for refining, chemicals, steel, or fleet fueling.

Execution tip: Secure a nearby H₂ buyer and grid-connection plan, then size the unit to match steady waste inflow and hydrogen demand.

Access To A Steam Cracker Or Petrochemical Complex

Choose: Pyrolysis-oil conditioning targeting circular polymer loops.

Why it fits: Meeting cracker specifications unlocks high-value offtake and enables verifiable recycled-content claims inside plastics supply chains.

Best locations: Chemical parks with liquid-feed crackers and utilities for pretreatment, hydrotreating, and impurity control.

Execution tip: Budget for a full conditioning train and quality assurance. Align with a cracker operator on acceptable ranges for chlorine, oxygenates, metals, and boiling curves.

Regions With Strong CO₂ Fuel Credits and Low-Cost Renewable Power

Choose: CO₂-to-e-fuels such as e-methanol for marine use or power-to-liquid SAF for aviation.

Why it fits: Policy rewards low-carbon molecules and early plants are already operating with offtake agreements from shipping and airlines.

Best locations: Grid nodes with abundant renewables, available CO₂ sources, and port or airport infrastructure.

Execution tip: Lock power purchase terms and carbon intensity baselines early. Match plant size to firm offtake and certification requirements.

Markets Where Recycled-Content Claims Are Essential

Choose: Routes that trace outputs into polymer loops rather than combustion.

Why it fits: In programs where bottle-content accounting excludes fuel use from recycled-content claims, polymer-to-polymer pathways score better.

Execution tip: Track mass-balance rules closely, align auditing and chain-of-custody systems, and coordinate communications so claims match the local standard.

Putting It All Together: A Quick Decision Flow

Is reliable H₂ demand within trucking distance and are feeds mixed or dirty → pursue plastic-to-hydrogen.

Is a steam cracker nearby with appetite for circular liquids → invest in pyrolysis-oil conditioning for polymer loops.

Is cheap, clean power available and CO₂ credits strong → develop CO₂-to-e-fuels for shipping or aviation.

Are recycled-content claims central to revenue or regulation → bias toward polymer-loop outputs and mass-balance alignment.

Use this selector as a checklist in project scoping. Map your local variables, run sensitivity on power price and policy credit values, validate offtake specifications with buyers, and the winning route will emerge with far less friction.

The Bottom Line on Waste Carbon: What Smart Buyers Know Now

Sustainability has grown up. The popular DIY clips are a useful spark, yet the real story sits in contracts, certifications, and plants that turn waste plastics and captured CO₂ into fuels and feedstocks that meet buyer specifications.

Everyday infrastructure contributes alongside corporate hubs, with Biodigesters That Recycle Household Waste lowering household emissions and Ryanair’s Eco-Friendly Hangar Facility optimizing energy use across ground operations.

Shipping is already bunkering e-methanol in Denmark. Aviation is investing in power-to-liquid suppliers to secure future SAF. Petrochemicals are conditioning pyrolysis oils and testing fully circular, electrified cracking runs.

Policymakers are defining how recycled content is counted and how waste units are permitted, which directly affects what scales first. Review the Kassø facility’s production data, the United × Twelve investment, Coolbrook’s cracking milestone, and the EU mass-balance consultation to see how technology, markets, and rules now reinforce one another.

title: IndiGo Places Firm Order For 30 Additional Airbus A350-900s - Simple Flying
description:
As of Friday, October 17, IndiGo has finalized a firm order for 30 additional Airbus A350-900 models, ultimately converting a June Memorandum of Understanding and lifting its Airbus A350 backlog up to 60 jets.
Airbus noted impressive market growth in India, with Airbus A350 orders totaling more than 1,400 from 63 customers by September 2025.
What Is IndiGo's Plan For Entering The Long-Haul Market?
Codeshares also fill gaps until the Airbus A350 arrives to provide scale and long-range capabilities.
The Airbus A350 does offer top-of-the-line cabin comfort, so its introduction to service will mark an improvement over the 777-300ERs, which it will initially use.
text:
As of Friday, October 17, IndiGo has finalized a firm order for 30 additional Airbus A350-900 models, ultimately converting a June Memorandum of Understanding and lifting its Airbus A350 backlog up to 60 jets. This ultimately signaled a decisive move into the world of long-haul flying. The airline's CEO, Pieter Elbers, ultimately said that the deal supports IndiGo's goal of becoming a global player by 2030 and aligning with India's aviation hub ambitions.

The aircraft type promises a roughly 25% lower fuel burn, operating cost, and Carbon Dioxide output than previous-generation rival jet models. The plane can also operate with up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel, with a target of 100% currently in the works for 2030. Airbus noted impressive market growth in India, with Airbus A350 orders totaling more than 1,400 from 63 customers by September 2025.

A Deeper Look At The Specifics Of This Deal

IndiGo's firm order for a set of 30 Airbus A350-900s is set to lift its A350 backlog to 60 aircraft, and it is notable on several fronts. This order very quickly converts a Memorandum of Understanding from June, and it signals a strong conviction in the airline's decision to make a pivot into the long-haul market. IndiGo has historically been a very successful low-cost regional carrier, but this shift highlights the airline's strong interest in making an entry into the long-haul market, according to the latest reports from manufacturer Airbus.

The Airbus A350's long-range capabilities, cabin comfort, and roughly 25% advantage in terms of fuel burn make it a good choice for an airline looking to cater to a new kind of long-haul travelers. The jet's exceptional route economics and ability to operate with nearly 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel make it exceptionally capable in relation to earlier-generation competitors. The carrier will now begin the challenging part of planning which long-haul destinations it is looking to fly to.

What Is IndiGo's Plan For Entering The Long-Haul Market?

IndiGo is pursuing a sequenced and risk-managed pivot into long-haul travel. This is relatively unique for an airline that operates on a low-cost model, given the typical higher expenses associated with long-haul intercontinental flights. The airline is starting by layering partnerships across its network to offer diverse one-stop access to destinations across Europe. The airline is then looking to wet-lease Boeing 777-300ER models to build up experience operating services between Delhi, Mumbai, and Istanbul.

Next, IndiGo added a small "Stretch" premium cabin on Airbus A321neos to test paid upsell potential and condition customers for two-class services. The airline's fleet architecture is based on a true long-haul model with some future Airbus A321XLR jets that will enable flights on long and thin routes. This will soon be followed by Airbus A350-900s starting in 2027, with this new order bringing the total number of airframes to 60.

The airline's network strategy will leverage Delhi and Mumbai as super-feed hubs, opening up European services first before broader Asia-Pacific and North America moves. Codeshares also fill gaps until the Airbus A350 arrives to provide scale and long-range capabilities. There are some risks associated with the execution of this long-haul fleet strategy. This includes improved slot access at primary gateways, and potential delivery delays could also slow down the airline's planned timeline.

What Does All Of This Mean For Passengers?

Passengers will now have access to more nonstop flights from India to Europe. Later expansion plans call for the airline to add flights to Asia-Pacific destinations and to North America, which will further expand the carrier's long-haul reach. Passengers traveling with IndiGo on long-haul services can anticipate competitive base fares, but an unbundled model that will require them to pay for pretty much everything extra.

In the near term, one-stop connectivity will continue to improve via the airline's partners. Medium-haul routes will use the Airbus A321XLR that features "Stretch" seats offering extra comfort. The Airbus A350 does offer top-of-the-line cabin comfort, so its introduction to service will mark an improvement over the 777-300ERs, which it will initially use.

The airline will operate two principal hubs using this aircraft. The airline will center its long-haul service network out of Indira Gandhi International Airport (DEL) in Delhi and Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (BOM) in Mumbai.

title: Singapore to impose green aviation fuel levy on flights - Bangkok Post
description:
SINGAPORE — Singapore’s parliament passed a bill on Tuesday introducing a fixed levy on departing flights to cut emissions and support the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by airlines.
The levy will be paid to the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, which will procure and manage sustainable aviation fuel, according to Senior Minister of State for Transport Sun Xueling at a parliamentary debate.
Singapore has set a goal to raise the use of sustainable aviation fuel to more than 1% by 2026, with plans to increase it further to between 3% and 5% by 2030 — a move it says will not significantly raise airfares.
Still, global adoption of the green fuel remains minuscule, with SAF poised to make up 0.7% of aviation fuel this year, while air travel is expected to climb 6%, driving emissions higher.
The city-state will aggregate SAF demand across airlines and procure the fuel centrally, allowing for better commercial terms with fuel suppliers, Sun said.
text:
SINGAPORE — Singapore’s parliament passed a bill on Tuesday introducing a fixed levy on departing flights to cut emissions and support the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by airlines.

The levy will be paid to the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, which will procure and manage sustainable aviation fuel, according to Senior Minister of State for Transport Sun Xueling at a parliamentary debate.

Singapore has set a goal to raise the use of sustainable aviation fuel to more than 1% by 2026, with plans to increase it further to between 3% and 5% by 2030 — a move it says will not significantly raise airfares. The cost will be shared across all air transport users, with earlier estimates suggesting an SAF levy of S$3 (US$2.30) to S$16 for passengers on an economy class direct flight, depending on distance.

The International Air Transport Association (Iata) estimates that SAF can contribute around 65% of the reduction in emissions needed by the industry to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. Still, global adoption of the green fuel remains minuscule, with SAF poised to make up 0.7% of aviation fuel this year, while air travel is expected to climb 6%, driving emissions higher.

The city-state will aggregate SAF demand across airlines and procure the fuel centrally, allowing for better commercial terms with fuel suppliers, Sun said.

title: Honda Aircraft has set a new milestone for green aviation — successfully flying its HondaJet ...
description:
Honda Aircraft has set a new milestone for green aviation — successfully flying its HondaJet using 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
The test, performed in Greensboro, North Carolina, used a blend of HEFA-SPK and HDO-SAK fuels, proving that carbon-neutral flight is not just possible but practical.
Powered by GE Honda Aero HF120 engines, this achievement highlights how innovation and environmental responsibility can go hand in hand.
The HondaJet, already recognized as the most fuel-efficient jet in its class, is now paving the way toward a zero-emission future in private aviation.
text:
Honda Aircraft has set a new milestone for green aviation — successfully flying its HondaJet using 100% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The test, performed in Greensboro, North Carolina, used a blend of HEFA-SPK and HDO-SAK fuels, proving that carbon-neutral flight is not just possible but practical.

Powered by GE Honda Aero HF120 engines, this achievement highlights how innovation and environmental responsibility can go hand in hand. The HondaJet, already recognized as the most fuel-efficient jet in its class, is now paving the way toward a zero-emission future in private aviation.

title: Vision Invest and Air Products to Produce Sustainable Aviation Fuel for New Tashkent Airport
description:
Tashkent, Uzbekistan (UzDaily.com) — Saudi Arabia’s Vision Invest and the U.S.-based Air Products will launch production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for the new international airport in Tashkent, Minister of Energy Jurabek Mirzamakhmudov announced in an interview with Uzbekiston 24 TV channel on 15 October.
The minister also noted that, in partnership with Saudi company ACWA Power, a large thermal power plant has already been commissioned.
Construction is underway on a solar power plant in the Kibray district, two major wind power plants in the Bukhara region, and a 100 MW wind power station in Karakalpakstan.
“We have begun practical work on new solar and wind power projects.
According to Mirzamakhmudov, one of the key areas of cooperation with ACWA Power is training and capacity building.
text:
Tashkent, Uzbekistan (UzDaily.com) — Saudi Arabia’s Vision Invest and the U.S.-based Air Products will launch production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for the new international airport in Tashkent, Minister of Energy Jurabek Mirzamakhmudov announced in an interview with Uzbekiston 24 TV channel on 15 October.

The minister also noted that, in partnership with Saudi company ACWA Power, a large thermal power plant has already been commissioned. Construction is underway on a solar power plant in the Kibray district, two major wind power plants in the Bukhara region, and a 100 MW wind power station in Karakalpakstan.

“We have begun practical work on new solar and wind power projects. In addition, a large-scale energy storage system is planned to be launched in the Parkent district,” the minister said.

According to Mirzamakhmudov, one of the key areas of cooperation with ACWA Power is training and capacity building. An energy college with a new educational model will be established in the city of Shirin, Syrdarya region. Students will receive foreign language training and will be offered opportunities to work not only in Uzbekistan but also on ACWA Power projects abroad.

In addition, Saudi company Pemco plans to begin construction of two new gas-piston thermal power plants, each with a capacity of 200 MW, in the Samarkand region by the end of this year.

title: Jet fuel company's leader calls South Dakota 'a difficult place to do business'
authors: John Hult, Jeff Beach, Joshua Haiar
description:
The leader of the company that abandoned its immediate plans to build a $2.6 billion ethanol-based jet fuel plant in Lake Preston said Friday that South Dakota is no longer a friendly place to do business.
“South Dakota is a very difficult place to do business,” Gruber told South Dakota Searchlight on Friday.
It wouldn’t be a standalone ethanol plant, he said, but it could be a jet fuel plant that uses corn oil or ethanol, or be used as a chemical production plant.
Gruber sees a future where 70 of the nation’s approximately 180 ethanol plants use designs like Gevo’s to convert to jet fuel production.
The specter of eminent domain sparked landowner opposition, litigation and political activism in South Dakota, leading to the ban.
text:
The leader of the company that abandoned its immediate plans to build a $2.6 billion ethanol-based jet fuel plant in Lake Preston said Friday that South Dakota is no longer a friendly place to do business.

In 2022, Gevo CEO Patrick Gruber stood alongside South Dakota Republican Gov. Larry Rhoden, then the lieutenant governor, at the ceremonial groundbreaking for the project, billed as the largest economic development project in state history.

This week, Gruber and his Colorado-based company announced plans for a smaller jet fuel facility at an ethanol plant in Richardton, North Dakota.

Gevo bought the plant a year ago in the wake of South Dakota pushback on a carbon sequestration pipeline that was critical to the company’s Lake Preston business plan.

“South Dakota is a very difficult place to do business,” Gruber told South Dakota Searchlight on Friday. “Everything is oppositional. North Dakota is a breath of fresh air.”

Gruber said his company still hopes to build something on the 200-odd acres it owns in Kingsbury County at some point in the future. It wouldn’t be a standalone ethanol plant, he said, but it could be a jet fuel plant that uses corn oil or ethanol, or be used as a chemical production plant.

Gruber sees a future where 70 of the nation’s approximately 180 ethanol plants use designs like Gevo’s to convert to jet fuel production. Demand is growing, he said, and the U.S. can’t keep up with the petroleum-based refineries it has.

That’s long-term, though. Whether the Lake Preston site is a part of that conversation or is used for another offshoot of Gevo’s operations is also a ways off.

At this point, after watching opposition to the Summit Carbon Solutions pipeline drive policy changes over the past three years, Gruber said he’s wary of engaging South Dakota leaders.

In 2022, he said, there was strong support in state leadership for both the pipeline and Gevo’s Net Zero-1 complex in Kingsbury County.

Then the political winds shifted.

“Having lived through the change, I’m not doing that again,” Gruber said.

Carbon sequestration drives business

Summit Carbon Solutions had hoped to gather carbon dioxide from ethanol plants across multiple states and deliver it via underground pipe to a site in North Dakota for sequestration. In doing so, the company would cash in on federal carbon capture tax credits.

Gevo, were it to build its operations in Lake Preston and connect to that line, would be able to lower the carbon emissions of its jet fuel, boosting its value in certain markets.

Sustainable jet fuel developer moves priority from SD to ND amid Summit pipeline delays

Gevo’s North Dakota plant sits atop the same formation that would be used to sequester carbon by Summit. This year, Gevo’s been pumping the carbon from that plant underground and selling carbon credits to other companies that want to offset their carbon footprint. Sequestering carbon also lowers an ethanol plant’s carbon score, so Gevo can sell it for more in some areas.

Gruber said the company can also sell carbon to fossil fuel companies in North Dakota’s oilfields for use in enhanced oil recovery — pumping gas underground to force more crude oil toward a well.

“We did good by buying that plant,” Gruber told Searchlight.

Summit, meanwhile, is in limbo. Gov. Rhoden signed a bill banning the use of eminent domain by carbon pipeline companies this year. Eminent domain is the legal process by which land access can be obtained for use in projects that benefit the public, with compensation for landowners determined by a court. The specter of eminent domain sparked landowner opposition, litigation and political activism in South Dakota, leading to the ban.

The Public Utilities Commission denied Summit’s permit application twice, but the company vowed to reapply.

Issue splits governor candidates

On Thursday, Rhoden said he’s glad to hear that Gevo may still build in South Dakota. He also said signing the eminent domain ban for carbon pipelines was the right thing to do in response to citizen concerns, and that Summit has a chance to “reset” its plans and work with landowners.

Rhoden has not announced if he’ll be a candidate to keep his job in 2026, but he’s spent much of his first year in office on an “Open for Opportunity” tour to meet business leaders across the state.

South Dakota Speaker of the House Jon Hansen, R-Dell Rapids, was the first Republican to announce his intention to run for governor. He’s been among the loudest opponents of the carbon pipeline.

Hansen said he’s not saddened to hear about Gevo’s shift to North Dakota. He pointed to a $12.2 million tax rebate authorized for Gevo by the Governor’s Office of Economic Development in 2023 and said companies ought to be able to thrive in South Dakota without incentives.

“This is yet another example of what I’ve been fighting against: politicians and bureaucrats in the Governor’s Office of Economic Development getting duped by green-energy and other scams — abusing so-called ‘economic development’ programs to hand out our tax dollars to out-of-state corporations.”

Hansen said South Dakotans “want our money back,” and that “corporate welfare waste” would end if he were elected governor.

Gruber said Friday, however, that Gevo never used its tax rebate, because it was predicated on building the Net Zero-1. Since that hasn’t happened, “we have not taken any money from South Dakota.” Josie Harms, Rhoden’s spokeswoman, confirmed that Gevo hasn’t collected any state money, and that it has paid sales taxes on anything it purchased in South Dakota to prepare the site.

Nothing has been done to the land for about two years.

Governor race exposes divergent paths on economic development among South Dakota Republicans

Another Republican candidate for governor, Aberdeen businessman Toby Doeden, also leaned in on opposition to publicly funded economic development incentives in his statement on Gevo. He said companies that want to locate in South Dakota should “share our values” and be able to “succeed without politicians putting their fingers on the scale.”

“As governor, I will attract businesses, large and small, who will come here on fair terms,” Doeden said in a statement. “Businesses that move here should do so on their own two feet without demanding hundreds of millions in state subsidies or abusing residents in the process.”

Republican U.S. Rep. Dusty Johnson, who’s also declared his candidacy for governor in 2026, has talked recently about wanting to make South Dakota’s business climate more friendly again. This week, he sent out a press release on a “Data Centers Done Right” initiative, which he said would incentivize their placement in South Dakota and make the state “be a national leader in the AI revolution.”

Hansen and Doeden each responded to that announcement by saying they’re opposed to tax breaks.

Johnson, in a statement on the Gevo situation, said anti-development attitudes are the reason the state lost ground in the latest iteration of CNBC’s “America’s Top States for Business” rankings.

“Unfortunately, this isn’t the only project looking to leave South Dakota,” Johnson wrote. “Our state has slid down the rankings to the 35th best state for business. South Dakota has many strengths, but if we are going to meet our potential, we’ll need vision and a plan.”

Robert Arnold, the only declared Democratic candidate for governor, said South Dakotans have made their feelings on the carbon pipeline clear. But he also said he’d like to see Gevo follow through and build in South Dakota.

“I hope that we haven’t turned this industry completely away from us and we can negotiate a deal down the road,” Arnold said in a statement.

Lake Preston anticipated loss

Lake Preston Mayor Donna Bumann said pipeline opposition wasn’t an issue in her community.

“For the farmers in our area that Summit has connected with, it’s been quite positive,” Bumann said. “I realize that’s not the same in other areas.”

Gevo trumpets cash on hand, growth potential for sustainable jet fuel in earnings call

Bumann said her community had embraced Gevo and the benefits its proposed jet fuel plant promised. In a presentation offered to investors last year, the company included a slide that said Net Zero-1 would return $170 million annually to the South Dakota economy, create 1,300 short-term and 100 long-term jobs, partner with universities to promote science education and draw graduates to its operations, and pay area farmers a premium for corn.

“We are hopeful that, in due time, circumstances will make it possible for Gevo to move forward,” Bumann said.

Kingsbury County Commission Chairman Kyle Lee wasn’t surprised by the news, either.

“Once the state said that they weren’t going to allow for Summit to do any eminent domain, I think we knew that was going to end up being the straw that broke the camel’s back,” Lee said.

Net Zero-1’s footprint would’ve included an ethanol plant, a plant to turn that ethanol into jet fuel, and a wind farm proposed by a company called Zero6. It also spurred East River Electric Cooperative to invest in a switching station near the Gevo site, meant to help service the company’s power needs.

This month, however, Zero6 pulled its application for interconnection from the Southwest Power Pool’s queue. The Southwest Power Pool manages the wholesale power market for the central U.S.

Chris Studer of East River Electric said the cooperative will still build its switching station and use it to serve existing customers.

“We weren’t just building lines to serve Gevo,” Studer said, but he added that the upgrades will ready the area for any large-scale industrial project that might come along.

title: IP Group's investments are paying off - ICYMI | LSE:IPO - Proactive Investors
description:
IP Group PLC (LSE:IPO) CEO Greg Smith joined Proactive to discuss the company’s strategic outlook, recent exits, and high-potential investments.
So it's a significant potential source of future value for IP Group and its shareholders.
When might IP Group realistically start seeing milestone payments or royalties from this pipeline?
Ongoing long-term revenue streams fit well with the long-term business model we have at IP Group.
Are we seeing a broader crystallisation phase for the IP Group portfolio?
text:
IP Group PLC (LSE:IPO) CEO Greg Smith joined Proactive to discuss the company’s strategic outlook, recent exits, and high-potential investments.

Topics include future royalty streams from obesity drug programs, portfolio realisations, and IP Group’s backing of clean tech innovator OXCCU.

Here, we take a closer look at what was said.

Proactive: Greg, very good to speak with you this morning. With Pfizer acquiring Metsera for up to $7.3 billion, how meaningful could future royalty income from these obesity drug programs be for IP Group?

Greg Smith: This is quite an interesting development. So this is something that we spoke a little bit about at our half-year results. As a part of our business, we have some patents that we license and manage, and this is one of those examples. I think the announcement that Pfizer was acquiring Metsera has shone an additional light on this area of our business — something we feel has been a little bit overlooked by the market.

So we felt it deserved a bit of an update in the spirit of our commitment to transparency. Pfizer is paying almost $5 billion upfront to acquire Metsera and its anti-obesity drug programs. It’s interesting for IP Group because we are the licensor of the fundamental underlying technology behind their lead compounds and a number of others. If those compounds successfully progress through phase two, phase three, and reach the market, then we could benefit from some quite substantial royalties on drug sales. So it's a significant potential source of future value for IP Group and its shareholders.

Proactive: Metsera’s lead drug is heading into phase three next year. When might IP Group realistically start seeing milestone payments or royalties from this pipeline?

Greg Smith: Interestingly, Metsera recently said they’re accelerating the timetable due to strong progress. They’re targeting getting the phase three trial up and running by the end of this year, which is good news. Analyst forecasts suggest first sales might come in 2029 or 2030.

The majority of our value would come once sales begin, so 2029, 2030 and beyond. It’s worth pointing out these compounds were produced by Professor Stephen Bloom at Imperial College London. Back in 1996, his team discovered that GLP-1 suppresses appetite, laying the groundwork for these therapies. So it’s a high-quality source, which is why we're particularly excited about this opportunity.

This is a very big market, and the drugs have the potential to impact hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of patients. It’s another great example of how IP Group backs developments that target big markets with human impact and significant financial return potential.

Proactive: Does this potential royalty stream change how you think about IP Group's growth model — from being an early-stage investor to holding longer-term revenue interests in late-stage assets?

Greg Smith: It’s an interesting question. It could be of such magnitude over time that we need to think about how we articulate this in our strategy and monetisation plans for shareholders. Ongoing long-term revenue streams fit well with the long-term business model we have at IP Group. It’s one of the benefits of having a permanent capital vehicle that can invest over the long term and grow businesses to material value.

Proactive: It's been a busy period for IP Group. You announced three successful exits recently, including the sale of Monolith to Nasdaq-listed CoreWeave. Are we seeing a broader crystallisation phase for the IP Group portfolio?

Greg Smith: You probably remember that 2022 and 2023 were tough years for the venture market. Last year, we bucked the trend with good progress on realisations — around £160 million in 2024. That included major exits like Featurespace to Visa and Garrison Technology to Everfox.

There’s increasing confidence within IP Group that our portfolio is maturing and attractive for exits, especially in areas suitable for M&A. The CoreWeave exit is another example of the portfolio’s quality. It probably wasn’t a company many shareholders knew about, yet we delivered a strong financial result.

At our full-year results, we said we’re confident in achieving over £250 million in realisations from our private portfolio between 2025 and 2027. This is another positive sign in that direction.

Proactive: Greg, you're also investing £4 million into OXCCU as part of a broader fundraising. Encouraging to see your portfolio getting lots of third-party interest?

Greg Smith: Yes. Exits are the end of the line — that’s where we recycle capital into buybacks or reinvest in the next generation of value-creating companies.

OXCCU is one of those. They’ve just closed a $28 million funding round. What’s interesting is the breadth and depth of investors — including Safran Corporate Ventures and International Airlines Group (IAG), the parent of British Airways. Also involved were other clean tech investors like Clean Energy Ventures from the US.

It’s great to be in a financial position to support this business into its next growth stage. They're based in Oxford and have their proving plant on Oxford Airfield. Many airlines are now committing to including SAF (sustainable aviation fuel) in their fuel mix by 2030, 2040 and 2050.

IAG said they want 10% of their fuel mix to be SAF by 2030 — and that’s not far off. So this investment helps them meet that commitment. The regulatory and industry drivers suggest a bright future for OXCCU. It’s a great example of a British company tackling global problems and attracting strong specialist investment.

title: Air France, Delta, Lufthansa, and United Airlines Lead Sustainable Travel Efforts as France ...
description:
Sustainable travel is welcomed, with Air France, Delta, and other major global airlines taking global sustainable travel goals integrate sustainability into airline travel.
Market players such as Air France, Delta Air Lines, Lufthansa, and United Airlines developed new and creative methods to minimize the levels of embedded emissions.
Delta Airlines Sustainablity Initiatives Delta Airlines is also one of the leaders of the travel industry when it comes to sustainability.
What Tourists Need to Know About Sustainable Travel in France France is a wonderful place to visit.
The future of travel is sustainable and sustainable travel is for all.
text:
Air France, Delta, Lufthansa, and United Airlines are leading the charge in sustainable travel, with a growing focus on reducing their carbon footprint and implementing greener practices. These airlines are taking significant steps to integrate sustainable aviation fuels (SAF), improve fuel efficiency, and invest in new aircraft technologies to combat the environmental challenges posed by the aviation industry. Meanwhile, France continues to push for the World Bank to maintain its climate finance goals, advocating for increased support for climate-related projects despite pressure from other countries to shift focus. With these combined efforts, both the airline and hospitality industries are reshaping the future of travel, offering eco-conscious solutions to meet the demands of today’s environmentally aware tourists. As the world turns its attention to sustainability, these airlines and global initiatives are setting the stage for a more sustainable tourism experience, one that benefits travelers and the planet alike.

Sustainable Travel: France Preferring Climate Goals From The World Bank

As the travel sector continues to adapt following the pandemic, a shift toward sustainability has become more apparent. The sector’s commitment to reducing their carbon footprint, transitioning to green energy, and aligning with climate-action goals is encouraging. Sustainable travel is welcomed, with Air France, Delta, and other major global airlines taking global sustainable travel goals integrate sustainability into airline travel. France has been instrumental in climate action and sustainable finance, especially in encouraging the World Bank to keep sustaining climate finance goals.

This article explains the response of the airline and hospitality industries to the climate crisis, how it will impact travelers, the implications of Climate -Goal France’s World Bank position, and the future of sustainable tourism. Finally, we provide eco-travel tips and explain key flight information to guide travelers in sustainable exploration.

Air France, Delta, Lufthansa, and United Airlines Lead Sustainable Travel Efforts

In the past, the aviation sector has played a major role in contributing to worldwide emissions, but there are changes to consider in the hopes of eco-friendly customers. The primary carriers in the field recognize the need to introduce effective emissions mitigation plans and put them into action. Market players such as Air France, Delta Air Lines, Lufthansa, and United Airlines developed new and creative methods to minimize the levels of embedded emissions. For these carriers, the levels of embedded emissions are likely to decrease annually, as they use biofuels and other Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) frameworks and engage in various approaches to carbon offsetting.

Air France’s Commitment to Sustainable Aviation

Air France, the leading airline to put SAF into action, shows the impact positive measures can take on the climate, shifting to a more innovative and greener approach. Air France predicted to use more than 43,953 of SAF in 2024 and decrease 150,000 CO2 emissions. This shows Air France’s will and determination in the airline’s promise to climate mitigation greenery. It shows advancement to the projected 2030 10% of the Air France global fuel mix use SAF as a carbon mitigation strategy blend while increasing the positive aviation climate impact. Air France loophole travelers use greener methods and minimized the impact of their carbon footprint.

Delta Airlines Sustainablity Initiatives

Delta Airlines is also one of the leaders of the travel industry when it comes to sustainability. As part of sustainable travel for customers, Delta Airlines has the plan of obtaining net zero carbon emissions by 2050. As part of sustainable travel for customers, Delta Airlines has the plan of obtaining net zero carbon emissions by 2050. Delta has also focused on setting the cross-enterprise carbon council. Members of this council focus on saving on fuel costs. In 2024, this council saved the company $100 million by reducing fuel use by 44 million gallons. Delta Airlines is also focused on fuel efficiency, ecofriendly sustainable fuels, and innovative aircraft designs. This innovative aircraft designs that aim to lessen the carbon footprint of the airline industry.

Lufthanas Aviation Innovations

Lufthansa is also focused on decreasing carbon emissions and the use of sustainable aviation fuels. In 2024, this airline saved 71,952 tonnes of CO₂ emissions. In the upcoming years, this airline plans to release 200 new, more sustainable planes that are expected to enter the aviation industry by 2030. This signifies that passengers flying with this airline, can enjoy their trip and green travel without sacrificing their safety and comfort.#### United Airlines’ Green Aircraft Program

United Airlines also is also becoming environmentally sustainable. In 2024, United blended sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) with regular jet fuel. United plans to have net-zero emissions by 2050. Other investments to improve sustainability with green technologies include aircraft. Passengers traveling with United can relax knowing that the airline is cutting down the carbon footprint.

France Urges World Bank to Stick to Climate Finance Goals

The airline industry is becoming more sustainable and the hospitality industry is also just starting to become more sustainable. Much more on the global scale still needs to be done to prioritize investments focused on climate change. France is one of the global climate change leaders.

France’s Advocacy for Climate Finance

Despite some countries–including the United States–pressuring the World Bank to no longer provide climate finance, France has actively been encouraging the World Bank to continue. France endorses the World Bank’s new target of 45% of climate finance as an improvement from the previous 35%. Since the consequences of climate change are worse than they have ever been, France believes that climate finance is necessary so developing countries can make a more sustainable transition.

The Role of the Hospitality Industry in Sustainability

As the airline industry works towards a more sustainable future, so is a part of the hospitality industry. Major hotel chains such as Marriott, Accor Hotels, and Hilton are trying to lessen their impact on the environment by implementing energy-efficiency, conserving water, and waste reduction. For travelers in search of more environmentally friendly accommodations, these hotel chains are leading the way with their green building certifications and commitment to build more sustainable hotels.

Marriott Hotels: In 2024, Marriott started a new sustainability program aimed at cutting down on water and energy used at all of its hotels and resorts worldwide. Marriott is also going green-moving waste and responsibly sourcing materials. People looking for a greener stay will feel good about eco-friendly options with a stay at Marriott.

Accor Hotels: Since releasing a new sustainability plan, aimed at an overall 30% reduction in carbon emissions expected to be completed by 2030. Several eco-friendly initiatives have begun with solar power, new energy efficient appliances, and promoting sustainable tourist packages for visitors.

Hilton Hotels: Hilton is also doing the same. It is also doing the same by decreasing their negative impact on… waste reduction—in this case, a water saving plan. Eco-conscious stays would be informed through eco-positive stays.

Travel Tips for Eco-Friendly Tourism

The encouraging impact on sustainability within the global tourism sector must be mirrored by travelers. The following travel tips help close the gap to minimize one’s negative (carbon) footprint.

Pick Sustainable Airlines and Flights

To lower your carbon footprint, fly with airlines that use sustainable aviation fuel and participate in carbon offset programs. Air France, Delta, Lufthansa, and United Airlines have made strides in decreasing their emissions and improving sustainability in aviation, so these are the airlines to fly with.

Stay in Eco-Friendly Hotels

When making reservations, look for hotels that focus on sustainability. The Marriott, Accor, and Hilton chains focus on eco-friendly practices, such as making use of energy-saving bulbs, conserving water, and reducing waste. These hotels help support the green initiatives of the sustanability of the hospitality industry.

Take Public Transport and Walk

When you reach your destination, use public transportation or walk instead of renting a car. Many cities have great transit options, including electric buses and eco-friendly metro systems that have a lower environmental cost than private vehicles. By choosing these options, you can greatly lower the emissions of your trip.

Bring Only What You Need

When you carry too much luggage, it will increase the weight of the airplane, and it will need more fuel. While traveling, you should try and pack the bare minimum! Using a carry-on bag will help keep your luggage and the weight of your flight down. Also, you should always choose digital tickets and mobile boarding passes to conserve paper.

What Tourists Need to Know About Sustainable Travel in France

France is a wonderful place to visit. From the streets of Paris to the French Riviera, it is full of stunning and diverse places. There is something for everyone, and this is part of the reason France is one of the most popular places to travel in the world. Tourists should also keep in mind France’s growing concerns about overtourism and it’s negative environmental impacts.

Best Time to Visit France

The best opportunity to visit France is during the spring (April to June) or fall (September to October) because these months allow for comfortable temperatures. The crowds dwindle, and the ambiance is calmer, which is perfect for sustainable tourism. The peak tourist months are the summer months, where the tourism centers are overcrowded- for instance the Louvre and the Eiffel Tower.

Visit the Underrated Areas

By all means, feel free to visit the Eiffel Tower and Palace of Versailles, but do also visit the less crowded tourist areas. The Loire Valley, Provence, and Alsace are perfect for this because these areas provide a genuine, crowd-free experience of France and alleviate environmental stress on the key attractions.

Stay at Eco-Friendly Hotels

As I mentioned, you can reduce your carbon footprint by staying at eco-friendly hotels such as those belonging to the Accor Group, Marriott, and Hilton. Most of these hotels are recognized with “green certifications”- a clear sign that they responsibly carry out their operations.

Air France, Delta, Lufthansa, and United Airlines are leading the way in sustainable travel, embracing eco-friendly practices to reduce their carbon footprint. As France urges the World Bank to uphold climate finance goals, the airline and hospitality industries are joining forces to create greener travel experiences for tourists worldwide.

For All Passengers, the Future is Sustainable Travel

With the global focus on climate change, the airlines and hospitality sectors are the first to respond to the challenges of sustainability. Emission reductions and the implementation of environmentally friendly technologies by Air France, Delta, Lufthansa, and United Airlines creates confidence among travelers that their flights support the efforts of building a more sustainable future.

Simultaneously, France’s support of climate finance initiatives at the World Bank enables developing nations to receive the funds necessary to mitigate climate change. With the increase in the popularity and ease of access to sustainable travel, this is the perfect time for travelers to engage in eco-friendly behaviors. Flying with a sustainable airline and booking with a green hotel positively impacts the future of travel.

The future of travel is sustainable and sustainable travel is for all.

title: China Permits More Biofuel Producers to Export Sustainable Aviation Fuel, Sources Say
description:
China has approved another three biofuel refiners to export sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by issuing them quotas.
This brings the total amount of SAF quotas issued so far in 2025 to around 1.2 million tons, including the first such permits allotted to Zhejiang Jiaao Enprotech.
China has approved another three biofuel refiners to export sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by issuing them quotas, according to trade sources and a Chinese consultancy, a move that could see exports to Europe increase.
Shandong Sanju Bioenergy was allotted around 158,000 tons and Shandong Haike Chemical 370,000 tons, while EcoCeres received 260,000-300,000 tons of export permits, the sources and JLC said.
This brings the total amount of SAF quotas issued so far in 2025 to around 1.2 million tons, including the first such permits allotted to Zhejiang Jiaao Enprotech.
text:
China has approved another three biofuel refiners to export sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by issuing them quotas.

This brings the total amount of SAF quotas issued so far in 2025 to around 1.2 million tons, including the first such permits allotted to Zhejiang Jiaao Enprotech.

China has approved another three biofuel refiners to export sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by issuing them quotas, according to trade sources and a Chinese consultancy, a move that could see exports to Europe increase.

While Europe, the world’s second-largest aviation fuel market, has yet to set a mandate for the usage of greener fuel, Chinese biofuel firms are building more SAF plants and targeting the continent as a top export destination. China’s Ministry of Commerce, which is responsible for quota issues, did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

Shandong Haike Chemical, Shandong Sanju Bioenergy and Bain Capital-backed EcoCeres were awarded export quotas for a total of 788,000-828,000 metric tons a year, according to three industry and trade sources, and Chinese commodities consultancy JLC in a report.

Shandong Sanju Bioenergy was allotted around 158,000 tons and Shandong Haike Chemical 370,000 tons, while EcoCeres received 260,000-300,000 tons of export permits, the sources and JLC said.

This brings the total amount of SAF quotas issued so far in 2025 to around 1.2 million tons, including the first such permits allotted to Zhejiang Jiaao Enprotech.

It is not compulsory for the new recipients to fully utilise the allotted permits by the end of 2025, according to the JLC report, but it is also unclear if the companies need to re-apply for quotas next year. Zhejiang Jiaao exported its first cargo in early May.

title: IndiGo Finalizes Order For 30 Airbus A350s - Nasdaq
description:
(RTTNews) - India-based airline IndiGo has finalized a commitment for 30 Airbus A350 aircraft, converting a Memorandum of Understanding signed in June into a firm order.
This brings the airline's total A350 orders to 60.
Airbus noted that the A350 is already capable of operating with up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), and aims for all its aircraft to be 100% SAF-capable by 2030.
As of the end of September 2025, the A350 had secured more than 1,400 orders from 63 customers worldwide.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
